articles.headline: Amazon and Hachette Resolve Dispute
articles.snippet: The accord allows the publisher to set prices on its e-books, a major issue in a battle that led Amazon to discourage sales of Hachette books.
articles.abstract: The accord allows the publisher to set prices on its e-books, a major issue in a battle that led Amazon to discourage sales of Hachette books.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hachette won an important victory on Thursday in its battle with Amazon: the ability to set its own prices for e-books, which it sees as critical to its survival. But even as the publisher and retailer announced a negotiated peace after sparring since January, hardly anyone seemed in the mood for celebratory fireworks.

articles.headline: Sliding Oil and Gas Prices Give Americans More Money to Spend
articles.snippet: The effect of cheaper crude oil and gasoline is especially significant for those Americans largely left behind by an anemic economic recovery.
articles.abstract: The effect of cheaper crude oil and gasoline is especially significant for those Americans largely left behind by an anemic economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: American consumers are going to enjoy a more bountiful Christmas this year, thanks in part to a most unlikely source: Saudi Arabia.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz, Clifford Krauss and Dionne Searcey

articles.headline: Obama Plan May Allow Millions of Immigrants to Stay and Work in U.S.
articles.snippet: Ignoring Republican protests, President Obama will assert his executive authority to order a broad overhaul of the immigration system, including a plan to give work permits to millions, officials said.
articles.abstract: Ignoring Republican protests, President Obama will assert his executive authority to order a broad overhaul of the immigration system, including a plan to give work permits to millions, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will ignore angry protests from Republicans and announce as soon as next week a broad overhaul of the nation’s immigration enforcement system that will protect up to five million unauthorized immigrants from the threat of deportation and provide many of them with work permits, according to administration officials who have direct knowledge of the plan.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Julia Preston and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Borrowers in Hungary Learn Tough Lessons
articles.snippet: The story of how Hungarians wound up deeply in debt in Swiss francs is partly a story of European overconfidence during the boom before the credit crisis. But it is also a story of how poor regulation of banks can be disastrous.
articles.abstract: The story of how Hungarians wound up deeply in debt in Swiss francs is partly a story of European overconfidence during the boom before the credit crisis. But it is also a story of how poor regulation of banks can be disastrous.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many people in Central and Eastern Europe, a new experience began a quarter-century ago. Communist governments collapsed, and the wide world of private ownership, democracy and free markets opened up suddenly.

articles.headline: Secret Service Blunders Eased White House Intruder’s Way, Review Says
articles.snippet: A report by the Department of Homeland Security noted “performance, organizational, technical” and other failures that allowed a man to get inside the White House in September.
articles.abstract: A report by the Department of Homeland Security noted “performance, organizational, technical” and other failures that allowed a man to get inside the White House in September.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An intruder was able to climb a fence and enter the White House in September because of a succession of “performance, organizational, technical” and other failures by the Secret Service, according to a damning review of the incident by the Department of Homeland Security.

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Recasts Its Reputation to Woo Tech Talent
articles.snippet: In recruiting programmers from elite universities, Wall Street runs up against the idea that Silicon Valley is the technological promised land.
articles.abstract: In recruiting programmers from elite universities, Wall Street runs up against the idea that Silicon Valley is the technological promised land.
articles.lead_paragraph: A panel of Goldman Sachs employees spent a recent Tuesday night at the Columbia University faculty club trying to convince a packed room of potential recruits that Wall Street, not Silicon Valley, was the place to be for computer scientists.

articles.headline: For a Liberian Family, Ebola Turns Loving Care Into Deadly Risk
articles.snippet: The Doryen family, unbowed survivors of Liberia’s civil war, saw seven members die from the virus in a matter of months and lost its sense of unity.
articles.abstract: The Doryen family, unbowed survivors of Liberia’s civil war, saw seven members die from the virus in a matter of months and lost its sense of unity.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Days after Kaizer Dour died of Ebola at the edge of a mangrove swamp, strangers carried his rotting corpse in a dugout canoe for a secret burial. Out on an uninhabited, bush-covered island, far from the national basketball court where Kaizer won acclaim as one of Liberia’s most valuable players last season, the strangers fulfilled one of the most important duties of a Liberian family — burying the young man.

articles.headline: A Fatally Flawed Switch, and a Burdened G.M. Engineer
articles.snippet: Interviews with employees and documents turned over to Congress reveal a midlevel engineer who tried to satisfy orders for a smoothly functioning switch that would help G.M. improve the image of its cut-rate small cars.
articles.abstract: Interviews with employees and documents turned over to Congress reveal a midlevel engineer who tried to satisfy orders for a smoothly functioning switch that would help G.M. improve the image of its cut-rate small cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Raymond DeGiorgio was just another obscure engineer at General Motors — until the company blamed him for starting the worst safety crisis in its history.

articles.headline: Obama, Down but Not Out, Presses Ahead
articles.snippet: Following deep losses in the midterm elections, President Obama has flexed his muscles on climate change, immigration and Internet neutrality.
articles.abstract: Following deep losses in the midterm elections, President Obama has flexed his muscles on climate change, immigration and Internet neutrality.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama emerged from last week’s midterm election rejected by voters, hobbled politically and doomed to a final two years in office suffering from early lame-duck syndrome. That, at least, was the consensus in both parties. No one seems to have told Mr. Obama.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Julie Hirschfeld Davis
